item.title: Covid: Germany warns of 'exponential' rise in coronavirus cases
item.description: Health Minister Jens Spahn says Europe does not have enough vaccines to prevent a third wave.

item.title: Covid vaccine: PM receives AstraZeneca jab as he urges public to do same
item.description: Boris Johnson says he "cannot recommend it too highly" as he urges the public to get vaccinated.

item.title: PC's curfew sentence for 'terrifying' attack on woman criticised
item.description: Oliver Banfield's victim says she thought he was "fulfilling a violent cop movie fantasy".

item.title: Finland ranked happiest country in the world - again
item.description: Denmark is in second place, followed by Switzerland and Iceland in the World Happiness Report.

item.title: Coronation Street uses real couples as Covid kissing doubles
item.description: As a way around Covid restrictions, the soap has had real-life romantics standing in for actors.

item.title: Greek bull figurine unearthed after heavy downpour
item.description: A bronze statuette believed to be at least 2,500 years old is found near the ancient site of Olympia.

item.title: US President Joe Biden ‘doing fine’ after aircraft stumble
item.description: A spokeswoman said the president is "doing 100% fine" after slipping while boarding Air Force One.

item.title: Covid: UK death rate 'no longer Europe's worst' by winter
item.description: Six other countries were worse affected during the second wave of the pandemic, according to ONS figures.

item.title: Covid: Woman made redundant three times lands job after radio show
item.description: Annabelle Smith, who has lost three jobs during the pandemic, is offered a job by a panellist.

item.title: Covid: Queen and Duchess of Cornwall thank volunteers for 'wonderful work'
item.description: Her Majesty and the Duchess of Cornwall took part in a call with members of the Royal Voluntary Service.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon rejects claims over Alex Salmond inquiry evidence
item.description: Nicola Sturgeon says she stands by "every word" of her evidence to the Alex Salmond committee.

item.title: Police warn students to avoid science website
item.description: Universities are urged to block a science research website, which police say could put data at risk.

item.title: Nathan Evans' sea shanty Wellerman goes to number one in UK chart
item.description: Wellerman has gone from 19th Century seafaring song to viral sensation to 2021 chart-topper.

item.title: Covid: Sister raises younger siblings alone after mum's death
item.description: Chelsea-Leigh Richardson, 21, says she became mum to her four siblings overnight when her mum died.

item.title: Swan spotted rattling letterboxes on Northampton street
item.description: The cherry-knocking bird was caught on camera on a residential road.

item.title: Comic Relief 2021: Daniel Craig and Catherine Tate lead Red Nose Day stars
item.description: Catherine Tate, Daniel Craig and Keira Knightley are taking part in this year's Comic Relief.

item.title: Comic Relief 2021: Mentor for young men shares bullying struggle
item.description: Reece was bullied at school, leaving him with depression and anxiety, but now he's helping others.

item.title: Coronavirus: The student nurses behind the masks
item.description: Nursing students graduating in 2021 have trained in an unprecedented environment: A global pandemic.

item.title: Anti-Asian violence: 'He slashed me from cheek-to-cheek'
item.description: Asian Americans across the US have faced a surge in hate crimes during the pandemic.

item.title: Why Australian women are saying 'enough is enough'
item.description: Australian politics is often called toxic to women - now rape allegations have ignited national fury.

item.title: Jo Whiley: Sister Frances to get first Covid vaccination
item.description: Frances, 53, is due to have the vaccine after the virus left her "fighting for her life" in February.

item.title: Young Goldman Sachs bankers ask for 80-hour week cap
item.description: First-year analysts have reported 95-hour working weeks plus poor physical and mental health.

item.title: Whinlatter Forest trees felled using specialist helicopter
item.description: Striking footage shows the trees being "magically" lifted into the air in the Lake District.

item.title: The Papers: Health chiefs back Covid jab and Sturgeon in peril
item.description: Regulators backing the Covid jab and MSPs saying Nicola Sturgeon mislead their inquiry lead the papers.

item.title: Oscars 2021: Nominees told Zoom attendance not an option
item.description: Producers say great efforts have been made to make the show safe to attend in person.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: Life in the UK, one year on
item.description: A year after the coronavirus lockdown in the UK, two people reflect on how their lives have changed.

item.title: Children’s Commissioner: Bereaved students need more help
item.description: The new Children’s Commissioner says the way bereaved exam students are graded, needs to be changed.

item.title: Why are some towns struggling to shake off Covid-19?
item.description: Some towns in the North of England and the Midlands are struggling to get Covid infection rates down.

item.title: How Covid has changed where we want to live
item.description: Cornwall has overtaken London as the most searched for location among property buyers, data suggests.

item.title: The 'insane' money in trading collectible cards
item.description: Prices of collectible cards are soaring and new digital products are entering the market.

item.title: Nevada smart city: A millionaire’s plan to create a local government
item.description: Jeffrey Berns wants to build a tech oasis in the Nevada desert. Do others share his utopian vision?

item.title: Covid: From boom to bust - why lockdown hasn't led to more babies
item.description: Research shows that the US and parts of Europe are facing slumps in birth rates.

item.title: Slavia Prague to file criminal complaint over 'brutal attack' after Ibrox game
item.description: Slavia Prague say they have lodged a criminal complaint over a "brutal attack" on Ondrej Kudela at Ibrox and include Rangers boss Steven Gerrard as a witness.

item.title: Derek Chisora and Joseph Parker confirmed, plus Katie Taylor v Natasha Jonas
item.description: Derek Chisora and former world champion Joseph Parker's bout is confirmed for 1 May as part of an exciting card.

item.title: Raymond van Barneveld being monitored after collapsing at PDC event in Milton Keynes
item.description: Five-time world champion Raymond van Barneveld is being monitored by medics after collapsing at the Players Championship 8 on Friday.

item.title: Cheltenham Gold Cup: Minella Indo wins from A Plus Tard for historic Henry De Bromhead treble
item.description: Minella Indo wins a thrilling Cheltenham Gold Cup under Jack Kennedy to deny Rachael Blackmore aboard A Plus Tard in a 1-2 for trainer Henry de Bromhead.

item.title: Liverpool face Real Madrid in Champions League - full quarter and semi-final draws
item.description: Liverpool will face Real Madrid in the quarter-finals of the Champions League, while Manchester City will play Borussia Dortmund and Chelsea will face Porto.

item.title: 'He is like Superman' - Jones set for Grand Slam history bid against France
item.description: Alun Wyn Jones could become the first Welshman to win four Six Nations Grand Slams if he leads his country to victory against France in Paris.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: How many people have had their vaccine in the UK?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 26 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are the latest group to be invited to book their Covid vaccine.

item.title: When will pubs, gyms and hairdressers open?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased, so when will places like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding and why?
item.description: Shielding in England will end on 31 March.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Wales and Scotland have announced the easing of restrictions on people meeting

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid-19: EU warns UK over vaccine exports
item.description: The EU threatens to block vaccine exports to the UK unless it "gets its fair share".

item.title: Coronavirus: How are the rules for weddings changing across the UK?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but there are plans to ease the rules.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: The government says it may still be too early to book summer holidays abroad.

item.title: EU plans for a 'vaccine passport' to allow travel
item.description: 'Vaccine passport' plans have been proposed by the EU, in order to make travel easier this summer.

item.title: Covid: When will children return to school and what are the rules?
item.description: Children are returning to school across the UK, after months of enforced home-schooling.

item.title: Lockdown Learning: What educational resources are on TV, iPlayer and online?
item.description: As most pupils return to school, the BBC will continue to offer a wealth of educational material.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Coronavirus: Data by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: What are the care home rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: What are the new rules for testing and hotel quarantine?
item.description: Travellers going to and from the UK face a growing number of restrictions.

item.title: Am I eligible for the new furlough scheme?
item.description: Furlough has been extended until the end of September.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.
